Award.AwardTitle: Northwest Engineering and Vehicle Technology Exchange

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The worldwide market for hybrid electric vehicle (HEV) and electric vehicle (EV) is growing steadily, with the United States taking the lead with over 500,000 HEV/EVs sold in 2013. This growth compounds when considered globally, with the forecast for the worldwide number of HEV/EVs on the in road in 2015 at 80.4 million. The west coast (Oregon, Washington and California) is the leader in HEV/EV ownership and development with nearly one-third (32.9%) of all HEV/EVs sales nationwide in these three states alone. This project at Central Oregon Community College (COCC) will prepare technicians to work in advanced HEV and EV diagnostics, maintenance, and repair. The establishment of a regional consortium, the Advanced Vehicle Training Group Northwest, will foster technology education opportunities for instructors and advanced automotive technicians across the northwest region. This collaboration will set and implement the standard for HEV/EV education. It will bring HEV/EV educational opportunities to rural students in Central Oregon, an area with a significant Latino and Native American population.

This project will support student learning in science and engineering technician education by developing new curriculum aligned with Society of Automotive Engineers (SAE) standards for HEV/EV certified training programs. This will add to the pedagogical knowledge in HEV/EV diagnostics, maintenance, and repair. In preparation for this effort, the college has conducted extensive research on automotive technology education gaps, has engaged in discussion with local and regional employers, has surveyed students and employers, and has investigated how other colleges statewide and nationally are addressing the HEV/EV education gap. This project will build on previously successful models for constructing alternative curricular pathways (often described as a latticed curriculum) to provide a rich tapestry of education and training opportunities for students at various stages of the employment cycle. It will also develop novel tools needed for alternative certification of skills through "open badges." This national initiative is still early in development and every implementation of the badging process in a community college will add to the collective knowledge and understanding of best practices in the use of open badges to build a new curricular framework for educators in academic and industrial communities. A comprehensive evaluation plan will measures student success by completion rates for certifications, degrees, and badges earned. Outreach activities to underserved populations will focus on strategies known to be effective in reaching such students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Goal - to develop regional capacity to train skilled technicians with the critical thinking and STEM skills needed to be valued employees and leader in emerging hybrid / electric vehicles (HEV / EV) powered industry in the Pacific Northwest.

Intellectual merit:

1. Support student learning in science and engineering technician education by developing new curriculum that strengthens HEV/EV education locally and regionally by providing college level and SAE endorsed education in HEV/EV diagnostics, maintenance and repair, including battery component "state of health" testing and repair.

2. Develop replicable models for training that can be used throughout the industry.

3. Develop novel tools needed for alternative certification of skills through "open badges".

Broader impacts:

1. Establish a regional consortium.

2. Bring HEV/EV educational opportunities to rural students and students underrepresented in STEM disciplines in Central Oregon.

3. Disseminate the open badge model as a basis for a new curricular framework for educators.

 

The first stage of this project was to validate that the proposed AAS Automotive Technology in Electronics and Diagnostics and associated certificates would provide the training to students and current technicians that would apply to the advanced technologies of HEV/EV and associated other advanced technologies in Clean Diesel and vehicle programing. Housed in the new Redmond Technical Center, we found that students were excited to be associated with the new series of courses.  Over 100 students were trained to enter into the ever changing workforce.

The new degree and associated certificates are a departure from how national Automotive Degrees are structured.  The COCC Automotive Program has held multiple conversations with other community colleges with Vehicle Electrification Systems training embedded within their curriculum.  PI Ken Mays visited five such community colleges to determine the scope of focus on electric drive vehicles at those locations.  The results and reports can be discussed with Ken Mays if contacted.

During the period of this grant the underlying digital structure and mechanisms of open badges were explored and developed as digital micro-credentials. As a result the co-PI has routinely served as a development resource for other members of the ATE community considering applications of micro-credentials. A number of badging software packages were explored and evaluated including Badgr, Credly, Acclaim, the Open Badge Factory, as well as hand built badges. Seventeen badges were awarded affirming the high voltage safety training of the students in the hybrid automotive program.

A major goal of this project was to develop a consortium of industry and community colleges to address the readiness gap in educators and technicians working with Vehicle Electrification Systems.  Advanced Vehicle Training Group NW has been formed and has been shaping into an organization that continues to make inroads in educational excellence.  The web site can be viewed at avtgnw.org.  Over the duration of the grant, eight face to face advanced courses have been offered with class sizes between 12 and 20 students consisting of college instructors, high school instructors, current technicians, automotive engineers, and manufacturer managers.   Just developed and offered is the new web based training available of the same web site called Access on Demand.  This development will be rolled into the next NEVTX2 Project Grant # 1700708 as advanced standards are developed for technicians working with high-voltage and high-pressure systems.

In reaching underserved populations in this region, PI Ken Mays coordinated multiple visits to classrooms and special events through the three year duration.  The project allowed for the hire of a bilingual automotive student to visit classroms of EFL students and promote automotive technology at targeted sites.  In addition, a team of faculty and staff from COCC were selected to participate in the NSF Institute for Women in Trades, Technology and Science (IWTTS) Program to help us recruit and retain women into the automotive trade.

Through the development of open badge tools and strategies there have been a range of impacts on the broader ATE and CTE communities beyond the badges awarded to students in this project. The team has served as a resource to other ATE institutions considering micro-credential programs. The deeper understanding of the potential of badges created by this work has led to a rich field of possible applications to other challenges from affirming softskills for student interns, tracking skills acquisition for credit for prior learning, to the development of new technical training standards.
